page.title: 02DARTMOOR PONIES
page.content: The earliest mention of Dartmoor Ponies was in the will of a Saxon Bishop in 1012. Ponies have been used on the moor for centuries to pull carts and tend stock. They were ideal beasts for transporting mined tin ore to the stannary towns. During the first world war Shetland and Dartmoor ponies were interbred to produce crosses small enough to go down mines as pit-ponies. There are few pure Dartmoor ponies today. In the summer there may be up to 2500 ponies on the moor. In the autumn they are rounded up and surplus ponies are auctioned off, many for slaughter as pet food. They are in danger from broken glass, plastic bags and rusty tins left by picnickers. Ponies may be seen all over the moor. Fencing and cattle grids prevent them from roaming off the moor.
